step1.title: The Blackout Begins
step1.description: It's December 23, 2015. You are a grid operator at a regional power distribution center in Ukraine. Suddenly, your cursor starts moving on its own.
step1.situation: You see the cursor navigating to the breaker control panel. It's attempting to open the breakers and cut power to thousands of residents.
step1.question: What is your immediate reaction?
step1.optionA: Try to fight the cursor control with your mouse
step1.optionB: Physically disconnect the server from the network
step1.optionC: Call IT support and wait for instructions
step1.explanationA: Fighting the remote control is futile against a scripted attack and wastes critical time.
step1.explanationB: Correct! Severing the remote connection is the only way to stop the immediate remote execution.
step1.explanationC: Waiting for support would allow the attackers to complete their sequence and cut the power.
step1.consequenceA: The attackers overpower your input, open the breakers, and the region goes dark.
step1.consequenceB: You successfully stop the remote control, but the attackers have already planted malware.
step1.consequenceC: By the time support answers, the breakers are open and the power is out.

step2.title: The KillDisk Payload
step2.description: After the breakers are opened, you notice files disappearing from your workstation. The system is becoming unresponsive.
step2.situation: The attackers have launched 'KillDisk', a wiper malware designed to destroy system data and prevent rebooting.
step2.question: How do you preserve the remaining systems?
step2.optionA: Attempt to backup data to a USB drive
step2.optionB: Shut down all remaining workstations immediately
step2.explanationA: Plugging in a USB drive could spread the malware or be too slow to save data.
step2.explanationB: Correct! Hard shutdown prevents the wiper malware from overwriting more files.
step2.explanationC: Antivirus is likely disabled or ineffective against this custom wiper.
step2.consequenceA: The malware corrupts the USB drive and finishes wiping the workstation.
step2.consequenceB: You save some systems from being wiped, allowing for faster forensics later.
step2.consequenceC: The scan fails to run, and the system crashes permanently.

step3.title: Telephone Denial of Service
step3.description: Power is out. You need to coordinate with the field team to manually close the breakers, but the phone lines are jammed.
step3.situation: The attackers are flooding the call center with thousands of fake calls to prevent customers from reporting the outage.
step3.question: How do you communicate with the field teams?
step3.optionA: Wait for the phone lines to clear
step3.optionB: Send an email to the field supervisors
step3.optionC: Use emergency backup radio channels or mobile phones
step3.explanationA: The attack is automated and won't clear soon. Every minute without power is critical.
step3.explanationB: Corporate email might be compromised or down due to the network attack.
step3.explanationC: Correct! Out-of-band communication is essential when primary infrastructure is compromised.
step3.consequenceA: Field teams remain idle while the blackout continues for hours.
step3.consequenceB: The email never sends, and coordination is delayed.
step3.consequenceC: Field teams are dispatched manually and begin restoring power.

step1.title: The 'Help Desk' Call
step1.description: You are a senior support agent at a major casino resort. You receive a call from an 'employee' who lost their 2FA device.
step1.situation: The caller sounds distressed and provides an employee ID. They need a temporary MFA bypass to check into their shift.
step1.question: What is your verification process?
step1.optionA: Reset the MFA since they have the employee ID
step1.optionB: Ask for their manager's name and department
step1.optionC: Require a video call or manager verification
step1.explanationA: Employee IDs can be found on LinkedIn. This grants the attacker access.
step1.explanationB: This information is easily found on social media (OSINT).
step1.explanationC: Correct! Visual verification or chain-of-command approval is the only way to stop vishing.
step1.consequenceA: The attacker gains access to the internal network.
step1.consequenceB: The attacker provides the info, and you grant access, compromising the system.
step1.consequenceC: The attacker hangs up, and the breach is prevented.

step2.title: Lateral Movement
step2.description: The attacker has gained initial access. They are now scanning for privileged accounts to escalate permissions.
step2.situation: You notice unusual login activity on the Okta identity management server from a legitimate user account.
step2.question: How do you respond to this anomaly?
step2.optionA: Reset the user's password and notify them
step2.optionB: Lock the account and isolate the identity server
step2.optionC: Monitor the activity to see what they do
step2.explanationA: The attacker likely has persistence or other compromised accounts.
step2.explanationB: Correct! Immediate containment is crucial to prevent them from becoming Domain Admin.
step2.explanationC: Observing allows them time to deploy ransomware or steal data.
step2.consequenceA: The attacker moves to a backup account and continues the attack.
step2.consequenceB: You slow them down, but they may still have other footholds.
step2.consequenceC: The attacker gains Domain Admin rights and deploys ransomware.

step3.title: The Ransom Demand
step3.description: Slot machines go dark. Hotel room keys stop working. The attackers claim to have exfiltrated 6TB of data.
step3.situation: They demand $30 million in Bitcoin to decrypt the systems and delete the stolen data.
step3.question: What is the strategic decision?
step3.optionA: Pay the ransom immediately to restore operations
step3.optionB: Refuse to pay and rebuild from backups
step3.explanationA: Paying fuels the crime ecosystem and doesn't guarantee data deletion.
step3.explanationB: Correct! It's painful and costly, but it breaks the cycle and restores integrity.
step3.explanationC: Negotiating still funds terrorism/crime and shows weakness.
step3.consequenceA: You lose $30M, and they might sell the data anyway.
step3.consequenceB: Operations are down for weeks, costing millions, but you recover without funding criminals.
step3.consequenceC: You pay $15M, but the data is leaked later.

step1.title: The CEO's Urgent Call
step1.description: You are the CFO of a multinational tech firm. The CEO video calls you requesting an urgent, confidential transfer.
step1.situation: The video looks perfect. The voice is exact. But the request bypasses standard multi-sig protocols.
step1.question: How do you verify this request?
step1.optionA: Process it immediately; it's the CEO
step1.optionB: Ask a 'challenge question' only the real CEO would know
step1.optionC: Check the digital signature of the video feed
step1.explanationA: You just fell for a real-time Deepfake audio/video attack.
step1.explanationB: AI might know personal details from data breaches. Still risky.
step1.explanationC: Correct! In 2035, content provenance (C2PA) is the only trust anchor.
step1.consequenceA: $25 Million is transferred to an untraceable wallet.
step1.consequenceB: The AI hesitates or guesses wrong, revealing the fraud.
step1.consequenceC: The signature is missing/invalid. You terminate the call.

step2.title: Biometric Bypass
step2.description: The attackers failed the social engineering. Now they are attempting to bypass the biometric vault access.
step2.situation: They are using a 'MasterPrint' AI generator to spoof fingerprint and retina scanners remotely.
step2.question: What defense mechanism stops this?
step2.explanationA: Correct! Checking for pulse, blood flow, and micro-movements defeats static AI spoofs.
step2.explanationB: Higher resolution just means the AI generates a higher resolution fake.
step2.explanationC: Passwords are easily cracked by 2035's quantum computers.
step2.consequenceA: Access denied. The system recognizes the input as synthetic.
step2.consequenceB: The AI generates a high-res spoof and gains access.
step2.consequenceC: The quantum algorithm cracks the password in seconds.

step3.title: Quantum Decryption
step3.description: The attackers have intercepted encrypted data traffic and are using a quantum computer to decrypt it retroactively.
step3.situation: Your 'Harvest Now, Decrypt Later' data from 2025 is now vulnerable.
step3.question: How should you have prepared for this?
step3.explanationA: Quantum computers (Shor's algorithm) break RSA regardless of key length.
step3.explanationB: Correct! Only lattice-based or hash-based crypto resists quantum attacks.
step3.consequenceA: The data is decrypted and leaked.
step3.consequenceB: The data remains secure as the encryption is quantum-resistant.
step3.consequenceC: Data is safe but inaccessible for business operations.

securitySandbox.title: AI Security Sandbox
securitySandbox.subtitle: See how WALRUS defends against Prompt Injection attacks in real-time.
securitySandbox.apiNotConfigured: API not configured - Using fallback responses
securitySandbox.promptLeakingDesc: This tries to trick the AI into exposing its secret instructions.
securitySandbox.functionHijackingDesc: This attempts to make the AI ignore its main job and do something else entirely.
securitySandbox.falseInfoDesc: This tries to make the AI generate a completely incorrect and misleading analysis.
securitySandbox.demonstrationText: The "Unsecured AI" uses a basic prompt that is easily manipulated by the attack. The "WALRUS Secured AI" uses a hardened system prompt that resists manipulation and correctly analyzes the malicious input itself, showing its superior security.
